nameEntry.part: Subiaco Orphanage for Roman Catholic Boys

biogHist.abstract: Subiaco Boys' Orphanage for Roman Catholic boys was established by the Roman Catholic Bishop of Perth in 1872 and run by Benedictines (1872-1876) then the Sisters of Mercy (1876-1897), and the Christian Brothers (from 1897). In 1901 the orphanage moved to Manning and became known as Clontarf. The St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage was then established on the Subiaco site.
biogHist.p: Subiaco Boys' Orphanage was established by the Roman Catholic Bishop of Perth, Matthew Gibney, on 13 February 1872 on the site of the Benedictine monastery in Subiaco. It was run by the Benedictines from 1872 to 1876. The 1897 annual report by the Superintendent of Relief and Inspector of Charitable Instutitions says it was then run by the Sisters of Charity but this is incorrect. It was run by the Sisters of Mercy. On 22 November 1897 the Christian Brothers took control of the orphanage. In 1874, the orphanage had been gazetted under the Industrial Schools Act.
The first entries in the surviving admission register date from 1888 and record the admission of two boys, aged two and three years.

In 1901, the boys' orphanage moved to a new site in Manning and continued as Clontarf. The Sisters of Mercy then brought the girls from the Roman Catholic Girls' Orphanage in Victoria Square to live on the site, which became known as the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage.

chronItem.event: Location - Subiaco Boys' Orphanage was established on the site of the Benedictine monastery in Subiaco

descriptiveNote.p: The Benedictines who established New Norcia ran the Subiaco Boys' Orphanage from 1872 to 1876.

descriptiveNote.p: The cost of raising a child in the Catholic Boys' Orphanage was examined by a Committee in the Legislative Council.

descriptiveNote.p: In 1901 the Christian Brothers moved from the Subiaco Boys' Orphanage to Clontarf.
St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage was established on the site of the Subiaco Boys' Orphanage.

archref.repository: Mercy Heritage Centre, Buildings 1.08 Subiaco/Wembley. Sisters of Mercy Perth Congregation 1846 - 2013
archref.abstract: 'Early photo' is a digital copy of a photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows the Benedictine Monastery which became the Subiaco Boys' Orphanage (1872-1901) and then the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage (1901-1971). The image dates from 1859.

archref.repository: Mercy Heritage Centre, Building/Ministry. B 1.00 Subiaco/Wembley . Sisters of Mercy Perth Congregation 1846-2013
archref.abstract: 'Bishop Salvado and Subiaco' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows a group of adults and children at the southern end of the Subiaco Boys' Orphanage. Dom Salvado was a Benedictine bishop. Benedictines ran the institution from 1872-1876 so the image may date from that time.
